Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Multi-Scale Study of Transport Phenomena in Printable Electronics for Enhanced Microstructure and Properties

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Environmentally-benign roll-to-roll electronics and photonics fabrication using inkjet printing and direct laser patterning on flexible substrates is an enabling technology that will provide desired high-volume, low-cost production of flexible electronics. In this project, we have combined novel modeling and in situ experiments to understand the flow, heat and mass transfer induced by the interplay of wetting, evaporation, and self-assembly of inkjet-deposited materials during inkjet printing of functional materials on flexible substrates. The focus is on the mesoscopic scale, where Marangoni flow, evaporation, and particle self-assembly are directly observed.

Results from this project have been disseminated through fourteen archival journal articles, over twenty conference presentations, and over twenty invited seminars. Two Ph.D. dissertations and four M.S. theses have been completed. Courseware for virtual thermo-fluid laboratories has been developed by a senior design team. Four REU students have been supported. Two high school science teachers spent their summers working on the project and will transfer the technology developed to their students. Three senior design teams with a total of 12 students have been mentored. New collaborations with Xerox, Corning, CeeLite, and Trident have been established. Four visiting scholars from Sweden, Italy, France, and China have spent 3-6 months collaborating with our lab. 

 

 

 



 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 05/28/2015
Modified by: Ying Sun

Results from this project have been disseminated through fourteen archival journal articles, over twenty conference presentations, and over twenty invited seminars.
